Hello, hi. Just a quick question on real estate if I may, just looking at slide 74, and wondering what the 14.4 billion would be if it was gross as leverage? Have you got any idea what that would be? Presumably the summit things to which you refer is actually the Canadian business of 870, and I'm presuming that again is leverage within there and that's why you've written the value of the investment down by €115 million even though the Canadian commercial property market presumably hasn't moved by that much. Thank you very much.
The 14.4 is gross of leverage.
Right. And then the 8.6, is net leverage is that the difference?

Maybe to add to that, I mean the 14.4 is the total portfolio which contains both investments and that is the 8.6 which go directly via P&L and then there is another part which is development or which is real estate in own use which does not go via P&L. So, the distinction 14.4 and 8.6 is more a classification of how do we account for it. What you do see here is exposures and exposures indeed means that if there is leverage in there or for instance 30% then it means that the actual cash investment is lower because we have grossed it up. So, you're right in terms of the gross up but the reflection of 14.4, 8.6 is more an accounting classification.
Thank you.
Okay, one more.
Thank you. Our final question comes from Hans Pluijgers. Please go ahead you're your question.
Yes, good morning this is Hans Pluijgers from Cheuvreux. Do you hear me gentlemen?
Yeah, go ahead please.

I have got four questions, first of all looking at page 11 with respect to your assumptions on cost savings and increase in cost organically, you're saying 2% going forward over the next few years. What are your assumptions behind that with respect to inflation and also increase in FTEs? Is there any increase in FTEs included in there? And then looking to page 18, there you give some breakdown on equity in the Insurance business, of course you didn't want to give a full breakdown but you could you just give some indication on equity for the Japanese operations?

Is that about one third of the equity for Asia? Could you give us some flavor on that? And then looking at page 20, you're saying big impact, de-risking the big impact on your margins, investment margin in Insurance business and 13 billion in short-term paper is there any short-term change with respect to the policy to be expected, so that already you could see a quite sharp improvement in Q4, what's your policy going forward with respect to the de-risking? And the last question is on the interest margin, you've given already some outlook for the longer-term what you're looking at but for the near-term, especially deposit rates still are trending down. Do you still expect positive impact from that in Q4 in the first half of next year?
Okay. That's a lot of questions.
Yes.

Looks like I have to deal with them one-by-one. The first question you asked was the assumptions we have made on our costs and the FTEs. We have not calculated any increase in FTEs for the assumptions. And we have calculated there's an increase in our labor cost or loan cost by about 3% in the Netherlands in 2010 and then going forward with each year, 1% thereafter. And then for the other regions more or less in the same – in the same category. So those are the assumptions we have made and we plan to offset, let's say, any type of increases organically and there's the savings we can get in other areas. The next question Patrick?
In respect to the, I think you asked about capital in Japan of the three point it's about 600, approximately 600 million.
Okay. All right.

And then in terms of the general count I think the best page at least to focus on the U.S. part is on page four of the U.S. statistical supplement. So if you can see there we show the four quarters in '08 and the three quarters in '09. And, so that first two quarters of '08 were before the crisis, so, sort of the treasury position was less than, these are all on dollars a billion, and the short-term was in the 1, 1.2 billion range. If you look at where we are today the treasury position is 8 billion and the short-term investments is about 5.5 billion so you can see a significant increase and over time as markets improve you would expect us to over time to reduce that treasury and in the short-term cash positions to be more in line with what we've done historically.
So it's more a gradual process than real big steps to be expected...

You know it's a little bit hard to say that it would – we would re-risk as we see market conditions in the future change. So it's really somewhat dependent on how quickly the markets improve as to how we would change the weightings in the general account.

Yeah, I think on the margins it's a bit difficult one to give a forecast for precisely what will they do in Q4. I mean in Q4 there is always some offsetting factors I mean there is a bit lower economic activity nevertheless we have still positive re-pricing of our loan book. I don't expect any changes in the yield curve so net-net you know you might get a small increase but again it's too difficult to sort of forecast that exactly for one quarter.
But you don't see still any major impacts from on the deposit side because of due to term deposits rating off.

I always like to be a bit conservative on the end you see now in the Netherlands is you see that the environment is improving a lot because we could lower our rates and I think the competition followed on that part so that is a beneficial one but there is a certain point when that stops. I mean we still like to keep the clients. So it's in that sense. I don't expect a major boost out of that because of that we can lower rates a little further. We have more broader now in line with our other European countries.
Okay, thanks.
That appears to be the last question of the day. Please conclude with any comments you wish to raise.

Thank you very much for being on the call. We hope we have given you an explanation why we feel that this is the right thing to do splitting the company going with a strong bank and a strong insurance company. We will take our time to really implement it well and we will strongly manage our performance for both the bank and the insurance company before we make any steps to go forward in executing the split. So, again thanks very much for being on the phone and probably we'll see you in the next few weeks when we visit a few countries as well. Bye-bye.
This concludes ING's Accelerating the Journey Back to Basics Conference Call. Thank you for participating. You may now disconnect.
